LIDIF 0.1.0
  • Reference

    Performing Likelihood-based Investigation of Differential Item Functioning (LIDIF)

    LIDIF.Rd

    The function takes the output of `prepare_data` function and run the LIDIF procedure. Notice that the procedure incoporats parallel computing functions to boost the computation speed. Therefore, we strongly recommend run the function with multiple cores. Please refer to the arguments on specifying number of cores.

    Usage

    LIDIF(
  dat.list,
  cl_num,
  type_list,
  output_dir = NULL,
  int_bound = 3L,
  evalimit = 10L,
  stop_at = 0.01,
  maxit = 50L,
  optim_trace = TRUE,
  optim_reltol = 0.1,
  hessian = FALSE,
  variance = TRUE,
  initialization = TRUE,
  init_input = NULL,
  random_per = 0.05,
  replace = FALSE,
  init_nums = 30,
  init_maxit = 5
)

    Arguments

    dat.list

    The data list containing both the observed items matrix and enogenous variable matrix derived from `prepare_data` function.

    cl_num

    Number of cores LIDIF can use. The more the better!

    type_list

    A vector of characters containing the types of items (`binary`,`ordinal`). If the length of vector is 1, then the same type would apply to all items.

    output_dir

    The path to save intermediate results. The default value is NULL. If NULL, the results will be save in current working directory.

    int_bound

    The adaptive integration boundaries. The default value is 3, meaning the integration taking from -3 to 3.

    evalimit

    The number of quadrature used in the adaptive integration. The default value is 20.

    stop_at

    The absolute convergence tolerance. The default value is 0.01.

    maxit

    The maximum number of iterations used in the EM algorithm. The default value is 50.

    optim_trace

    Logical. Should track optimization process? The default value is TRUE.

    optim_reltol

    The relative convergence tolerance for M-step. The default value is 0.1.

    hessian

    Logical. Should return the numerical hessian matrix in optimization procedures? The default value is FALSE.

    variance

    Logical. Should calculate variance and covariance matrix in the end? The default value is TRUE.

    initialization

    Logical. Should start from random initialization? The default is TRUE.

    init_input

    If initialization = FALSE, specify your own initialization here. The default is NULL.

    random_per

    Percentage of random samples in initialization. The default value is 0.05.

    replace

    Logical. Should generate random samples with replacement? The default is FALSE.

    init_nums

    Number of random initialization. The default is 30.

    init_maxit

    Maximum number of iterations in initialization. The default is 5.

    Value

    An object of the class `LIDIF` that contains

    • `coefficients`: a list of the estimated DIF effects. with each sublist corresponding to an item.

    • `variance`: A list of the estimated variance of the individual coefficients, following the same order as `coefficients`. Return only if variance = TRUE.

    • `cov`: The estimated variance-covariance matrix for all the coefficeints. Return only if variance = TRUE.

    Details

    Denote the latent variable as \(Y\), the covariate matrix as \(Z\) and \(X_1,...,X_p\) are the observed items. For items with binary responses (0 or 1), LIDIF models $$logit(P(X_i =1)) = \alpha_i+\beta_i^TZ + \zeta_i^TZ \times Y$$ For items with ordinal responses (1, 2,...,\(M_i\)), LIDIF models $$logit(P(X_i \geq m)) = \alpha_{im}+\beta_i^TZ + \zeta_i^TZ \times Y$$ where \(m \in \{1, 2,...,M_i-1\}\) and \(\alpha_{i1} > ...> \alpha_{im-1}\).

    The model returns maximum likelihood estimators of all the coefficients and their estimated variance (by choice).

    The key to the estimation accuracy of LIDIF is specifying multiple random initialization in `init_nums` arguments. A trade-off is the more number of random initialization you specified, the longer it took to run `LIDIF`. But you could always speed up the process by running on multiple computing cores (specified in `cl_num`) arguments.

    For your reference, the default setting provides accurate estimation in simulations with 5 items and 2 exogenous covariates from 1000 observations. And the computing time was 1 hour with 5 cores using R version 4.0.2.

    Examples

     if (FALSE) {
## load the sample data (see `?LIDIF::binsurvs` for details)
binsurvs = LIDIF::binsurvs # The exogenous variables are age and sex.

## prepare for model fitting
dat.list = prepare_data(binsurvs$X, binsurvs$Z)

## LIDIF fitting
# The parameter specified is set to reduce the running time.
# In your analysis, please refer to the default value.
library(LIDIF)
res = LIDIF(dat.list = dat.list,
            cl_num = 5, # before running, please check if you have 5 cores
            type_list = "binary",
            maxit = 2,
            random_per = 0.5,
            init_nums = 2,
            init_maxit = 2)
}
